title: Blood Of The Eagle And Lion
opening: The Kingdom army departs from the Great Bridge of Myrddin and marches south toward Enbarr, the Imperial Capital. Meanwhile, the Alliance army follows from behind to invade Imperial territory, and the Empire has dispatched forces from Fort Merceus to intercept them. The curtain is rising on a conflict between the three armies, which will come to be known as the Battle at Gronder, held on the same plains that witnessed the Battle of the Eagle and Lion.

At Gronder Field, where the Battle of the Eagle and Lion was once held, the house leaders of five years ago have a fateful reunion...but this time, the contest between the Empire, the Kingdom, and the Alliance is no mock battle.

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: What do you want?

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: Where are you going?

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: It doesn't concern you.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: It does.

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: Get out of my way. Now.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: You're going to Enbarr, aren't you?

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: Do you really think that will appease the dead?

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: Silence. You have no idea what you're talking about. Death is the end. No matter how much lingering regret a person has, after death, they are powerless. They cannot even wish for revenge, much less seek it out. Hatred. Regret. Those burdens fall on the shoulders of those who are left behind. And so I must continue down this path! I already told you as much! It is far too late to stop.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: You're wrong.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: There must be another way.

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: Do not waste your breath with some nonsense about how I should move on with my life for their sake. That is merely the logic of the living. It's meaningless. Those who died with lingering regret... They will not loose their hold on me so easily.

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: But you seem to have all the answers... So tell me, professor. Please, tell me... How do I silence their desperate pleas? How do I... How do I save them?

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: Ever since that day nine years ago... I have lived only to avenge the fallen. Even my time at the Officers Academy was all so that I could secure my revenge and clear away the regret of the dead. It was the only thing that kept me alive... My only reason to keep moving forward...

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: You must forgive yourself.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: You've suffered enough.

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: Hmph.

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: But then who... or what... should I live for?

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: Live for what you believe in.

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: What I believe in... Rodrigue said the same thing. But is it possible... I am a murderous monster. My hands are stained red. Could one such as I truly hope for such a life? As the sole survivor of that day, do I... Do I have the right to live for myself?

dialogue.speaker: Dimitri
dialogue.line: Your hands are so warm... Have they always been?

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: I can finally kill her... Finally... I can avenge them...

conversation.speaker: Dedue
conversation.line: You have my sincerest gratitude. Circumstances, and my wounds, have prevented me from being by His Highness's side these five years. I am grateful that you have found him for me. I am once again in your debt.

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: As powerful as our knights are, we're outnumbered. By a long shot. This won't be easy. It's crazy to attempt this. I guess I'm crazy to go along with it.

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: If we defeat the Imperial army at Gronder Field, what will our next objective be? I guess we won't have much choice but to try to take Fort Merceus, on the far side of Gronder Field. It's probably too soon for us to be thinking about that, isn't it? The battle just ahead of us is far from certain.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Say we do manage to take down Edelgard here... What do you think His Highness will do next? As long as there's a plan, I won't complain. I just, you know, wanna know there is a plan.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Continue on to the Imperial capital?

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Yeah, I suppose that's the most likely plan since we're traveling with the church and everything.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Head to the Kingdom capital first?

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Heh, well, I'd be happy if that were the case, but I don't figure that'll actually happen. All this isn't just going to magically end the moment we kill Edelgard. It's gone too far.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I don't know...

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Heh, well, if even you can't say, I guess it's not surprising the rest of us don't know either.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: I suppose we should focus on the battle right in front of us instead of what happens later.

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: So, we're finally going to set foot in the Empire... I'm starting to get a little nervous. I guess there's a good chance we'll be fighting more old friends from here on out.

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: The thought of fighting people who were once our friends...it makes my heart heavy. If it was gonna come to this, maybe I should have avoided making friends with people from the Empire and the Alliance to begin with...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You might be right.

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: You think so too, Professor? I'm glad it's not just me.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I don't think that's the right attitude.

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: I just don't know, Professor. I'm having a hard time with it.

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: It did often seem strange to me at the academy that we were studying with all these people from all over the world. But I feel like I've finally started to understand the real reason behind it. The more you get to know people from other places, the harder you'll try to avoid fighting wars with them...

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: Yet another grand battle awaits. Many will lose their lives.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: There's no way around it.

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: I am well aware. This is war, after all.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Let's fight our hardest to stay alive.

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: Yes, let's. We must both make it home in one piece.

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: Even considering those we are up against--friends from a time now past--I won't hold back.

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: We captured the Great Bridge of Myrddin, but the fight has only just begun. Enbarr, the Imperial Capital, lies far to the south, beyond Gronder Field. And waiting for us on the way there is the entire Imperial army, with twice as many troops as us. We had better brace ourselves.

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: I seem to lack the skills required to grieve for the dead. If someone has passed, even someone dear to me, I could stand about and wail or get on with my life. While I'm at it, that whole idea that we must speak well of the dead? I don't understand that either. If I didn't like them when they were alive, then why pretend to do so when they are no longer here?

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: After we cross the Great Bridge of Myrddin, we'll be in my father's territory. We actually crossed it five years ago for the Battle of the Eagle and Lion. Remember? Ugh! This is terrifying! What am I gonna do? I gotta get a grip...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Don't worry, I'll arrange for your funeral.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: You think we'll meet him on the battlefield and he'll kill me? The front lines cover a long stretch of land, you know! We might not even run into him!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I'll pray for your safety.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: Oh, no no no. You should pray we don't run into him at all! The front lines cover a long stretch of land, you know!

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: So the campaign continues, does it? Well, allow me, as a professional recluse with ten years of experience, to volunteer for, um...staying behind. Oh, who am I kidding? The fighting won't stop until we've defeated Edelgard, will it? Or until we lose, I guess. But there's not much use in thinking about that.

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: The Great Bridge of Myrddin was considerably better fortified that it was five years ago... The bridge was full of soldiers...and they all died.  And Ferdie was there. We killed Ferdie, Professor, he used to be our friend. Do you remember those days?

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: Nobles who are changing allegiance, again and again. I do not have understanding for that. How can you trust if treason comes with ease? How can you be calling yourself a noble? I do not have understanding of the reasoning...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: They're struggling for survival too.

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: Surviving is more difficult without trust. There must be...some other goal.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: For personal gain.

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: Survival has more importance than that. Are they not knowing this?

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: So, Claude and my father have made peace. That is to be expected. They both prioritize their own interests above all else. So long as those interests are in alignment, they will continue to cooperate. And based on that reasoning, one might infer that the Alliance should be also willing to work with the Kingdom's military. I highly doubt Claude would refuse to assist us, if we were to ask.

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: I gotta say, it's tough to keep the fighting spirit alive when you recognize your enemies on the battlefield.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Everyone gets that feeling.

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: So you can't avoid it, huh? How did everything get so messed up?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: You can run away if you want.

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: Hey, come on! Even I know we can't do that!

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: Just because we're fighting someone doesn't mean we gotta hate 'em! That's probably the worst thing about war. Win or lose, I still get a bad taste in my mouth.

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: Thanks to our victory, I've been able to study the Great Bridge of Myrddin at my leisure. And you know what? It's an astounding structure. So much history there. Imagine how much time and effort it must have taken to build something that big. Over water, no less! I hope that someday it will be opened up to the people of Fódlan--a historical site, rather than a military checkpoint.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: I'm glad you're the one giving orders on the battlefield, Professor. I don't think we should trust Dimitri with that task... Although it's thanks to his obsession that we're wasting no time, taking the shortest route to defeating the Empire. I just can't see a bright future for this army, fighting as we are under the banner of a prince possessed. Even if we do succeed in defeating the Empire, I wonder what will become of Fódlan. I apologize. Whenever I'm with you, I speak more openly than I should. Please keep this between us.

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: The situation in the Alliance has changed so much, but I haven't heard a word from my adoptive father... Do you think he's forgotten about me?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I'm sure he's just busy.

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: If that's the case, I hope he gets even busier.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I'm sure that's not the case.

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: I'm not overly concerned about him...

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: I'd actually be happier if he really did forget about me. Everything would be so much easier...

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: I heard the next battle might take us to Gronder Field. Is that right? Reminds me of the Battle of the Eagle and Lion. But of course, that was a very different time. When it was over, all three class heads complimented each other on their bravery. And then we had a party. But we can never go back to that, can we?

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: I heard Edelgard is going to be leading her forces personally in the next battle. Seems pretty reckless to charge right into this one. I'm not sure I like our chances. What do you think?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Don't worry. I can handle it.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: I don't know why you're so confident, but it does somehow make me feel better.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: As long as you're here, I'll be fine.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: Hey, how come you only ever flatter me in times like these? What am I supposed to make of that?

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: Anyway, we've come this far. Let's just keep putting one foot in front of the other and see how far we get.

conversation.speaker: Seteth
conversation.line: Each time we press forward, our search for Rhea broadens to a wider area. I certainly hope we will find at least some clue, but I do suspect I already know where she is. If I am right, and she is in the Imperial capital, then we cannot save her until we topple the Empire.

conversation.speaker: Flayn
conversation.line: The Battle of the Eagle and Lion. Has it truly been five years since then? Can you recall whether it was before or after I joined your class, Professor?

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Before.

conversation.speaker: Flayn
conversation.line: That is not at all the case, Professor. Your memory serves you poorly.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: After.

conversation.speaker: Flayn
conversation.line: I am glad you have not forgotten.

conversation.speaker: Flayn
conversation.line: It was shortly after I joined your class--I remember it like it was yesterday.

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: When undertaking research, the usual method is to form a hypothesis, then test it with experiments. Those experiments reveal facts and falsehoods, yet sometimes, they also unveil an exception. You seem to be that exception when it comes to my Crest research.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Sorry about that.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I don't understand.

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: Worry not, Professor. Exceptions are what make my work interesting. Why don't the rules apply to you? I will find out, eventually. I feel it is my destiny as a Crest scholar!

conversation.speaker: Manuela
conversation.line: I hear the next battle could be a big one, is that true? I miss the old days when, if someone got hurt, we'd rush them to the infirmary and make them well... But on the battlefield, there's not enough time to help. People die. Professor, don't be one of those!

conversation.speaker: Gilbert
conversation.line: Catherine will surely be able to convince Count Charon. All that remains is to wait for a response from the Alliance side... For now, there are preparations to be made for the coming battle.

conversation.speaker: Gilbert
conversation.line: Catherine has successfully convinced Count Charon. However... The knights we sent to the Alliance have yet to return.

conversation.speaker: Alois
conversation.line: Word just reached me that the Empire has stationed soldiers in Fort Merceus. If they decide to dig in their heels and defend the fort, we'll be in a difficult situation. I hear it's an impregnable keep, surrounded by high ramparts. Taking it would not be easy.

conversation.speaker: Catherine
conversation.line: Hey, Professor. It’s been a while... Well, actually not that long. If you’re here about the reinforcements, no need to worry. I’ve sorted everything out with my father. If the Alliance agrees to chip in as well, we might have a real chance at victory.

conversation.speaker: Shamir
conversation.line: Reconnaissance is becoming more of a risk the deeper we move into enemy territory. If I don't come back, assume I'm dead.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: I know you won't get caught.

conversation.speaker: Shamir
conversation.line: I'm glad you think so highly of me, but we have to be realistic.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Understood.

conversation.speaker: Shamir
conversation.line: Good. We have to be realistic.

conversation.speaker: Shamir
conversation.line: Don't waste your energy worrying about me.

conversation.speaker: Cyril
conversation.line: I gotta keep this place clean, and I mean properly clean, every day. Dust it, sweep it, everything. You never can tell when Lady Rhea might be back.

conversation.speaker: Rodrigue
conversation.line: Hm? Oh, it's you, Professor. Sorry, I was a little lost in thought there. About all that has happened, and all that is to come... I'm sure the battles ahead will not be easy, but please take good care of His Highness.

conversation.speaker: Gatekeeper
conversation.line: Greetings, Professor! Nothing to report! I hear we're sending troops to Gronder Field next. Is that what's what? That whole area is in the territory of House Bergliez. It's famous as the main granary of Fódlan. If we could capture it, we probably wouldn't have to worry about food anymore! Bread for all!

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: There's quite a bit of fog settling in. We won't be able to advance our troops very far in this.

intro.speaker: Rodrigue
intro.line: We won't be able to move at all until the fog lifts, no matter which path we take. We'll have to be patient and wait it out. ... Gilbert. No... Gustave. I would like to take this opportunity to speak with you about something. It's about the Tragedy of Duscur. There's something about it I just can't wrap my head around.

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: I'm listening.

intro.speaker: Rodrigue
intro.line: I lost a son in Duscur that day. I exhausted every last resource I had to investigate what took place there. I was startled to find that...there wasn't a single shred of evidence to suggest that Lady Patricia's carriage had been attacked.

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: Go on...

intro.speaker: Rodrigue
intro.line: Apart from His Highness, whose injuries left him on the verge of death, everyone else present at the time was slaughtered. Of all the victims, only the corpse of Lady Patricia, His Majesty's second wife, was never found. Isn't that right?

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: Hmm... Surely that means she was abducted. There was no evidence of an attack, suggesting they threatened her but did not kill her...

intro.speaker: Rodrigue
intro.line: But what reason would they have to take her? Would it not have been better to kill her?

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: Perhaps she had some value as a diplomatic pawn.

intro.speaker: Rodrigue
intro.line: Nonsense. In the many years since that day, has Lady Patricia ever been used thus?

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: No... Not as far as I know. Then perhaps she was used for some political gain within the Empire.

intro.speaker: Rodrigue
intro.line: Now that her daughter is the emperor, what reason would she have to keep hiding her existence?

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: It is possible she passed away after returning to the Empire...

intro.speaker: Rodrigue
intro.line: Gustave, I know this is hard for you to hear, but just consider what it would mean if Lady Patricia was involved with that incident...

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: Silence, Rodrigue. I will not allow you to tarnish her memory like that.

intro.speaker: Rodrigue
intro.line: I do not mean to imply that she arranged His Majesty's murder or anything of the like. But Gustave... I cannot shake the feeling that the tragedy was part of a much larger conspiracy. There is more to it than we know, that much is certain...

intro.speaker: Kingdom Soldier
intro.line: Rodrigue! Gilbert! Please, hurry!

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: To kill like this...is inhuman.

intro.speaker: Rodrigue
intro.line: This is one of the knights who was dispatched to the leader of the Alliance. Tell me everything you know.

intro.speaker: Kingdom Soldier
intro.line: Sir! A soldier on patrol came across this knight a short while ago in a rocky area not far from here. Someone from the Alliance must have disposed of the body there...

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: Is this how the Alliance chose to inform us that they have no intention of joining our cause?

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: Could Claude really have done this?

intro.speaker: Rodrigue
intro.line: The Alliance lords each have their own motives. It's difficult to say for sure who was behind this.

intro.speaker: Byleth
intro.line: Maybe it was the Empire...

intro.speaker: Dimitri
intro.line: Yes. I would not hesitate to believe them capable of this.

intro.speaker: Rodrigue
intro.line: Whatever the truth is, the other knights we dispatched are in serious danger. It's best to assume that joining with the Alliance is out of the question now.

intro.speaker: Gilbert
intro.line: Even with Count Charon's support, this makes our situation grim...

intro.speaker: Dimitri
intro.line: I never expected the Alliance to help us. Anyone who stands in my way will be crushed beneath my feet...

intro.speaker: Fleche
intro.line: It is time, dear Brother...

cutscene.speaker: Dimitri
cutscene.line: Know that I will tear your heads from your shoulders. The dead must have their tribute.

cutscene.speaker: Claude
cutscene.line: As big class reunions go...this one's gotta be the worst in history.

cutscene.speaker: Edelgard
cutscene.line: Years ago, we fought here as classmates. But not today.

cutscene.speaker: Dimitri
cutscene.line: Kill every last one of them!

battle.speaker: Dimitri
battle.line: You have finally appeared, Edelgard. Now you are mine.

battle.speaker: Claude
battle.line: The Kingdom army doesn't look interested in joining forces. Let's take a moment and see how this Unfolds...

battle.speaker: Edelgard
battle.line: It would not be advantageous to take on both at once. We must stop the Kingdom and the Alliance from joining forces. I will create such chaotic warfare that will not be able to tell who is friend and who is foe.

battle.speaker: Petra
battle.line: The center is in danger of being taken. We must be running to protect it!

battle.speaker: Imperial General
battle.line: There are enemies in the central area... We need to head there immediately to protect it!

battle.speaker: Claude
battle.line: Hmph. The Empire and Kingdom are mixed up in this battle. It's a struggle to target the right one. Such are the rules of Melee. We'll just have to crush anyone who isn't an ally!

battle.speaker: Claude
battle.line: They wanna crush us before the Imperial Army? Then we'll show them what we'll made of!

battle.speaker: Leonie
battle.line: Great! I may not have a Crest, but I'll give it my all.

battle.speaker: Hilda
battle.line: I'm not going to hold back. I can't let down my dear old Claude.

battle.speaker: Edelgard
battle.line: Those fools who went up the central hill will pay with their lives... in the crimson flames!

battle.speaker: Hubert
battle.line: The central hill is up in smoke. Suppose I'll have to quench the flames - with the enemy's blood.

boss.speaker: Edelgard
boss.line: I lost?! Just as expected, you aren't making my path an easy one. I must retreat for now. We'll meet again on the battlefield.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: So, you think you can escape, Edelgard?

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Your Highness! You're alive! We have to retreat to the Great Bridge of Myrddin...

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: That woman...we failed to capture her. I'll keep pursuing. The rest of you, keep fighting!

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: I'm so sorry...but we can't do that. I understand how you feel, but the Imperial army is closing in!

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: I'll kill all of them! No matter how many hundreds or thousands of them they are!

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: You... What are you doing here?! It's too dangerous! Fall back, now!

end.speaker: Fleche
end.line: Heh.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Your Highness!

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: You...are...

end.speaker: Fleche
end.line: Have I caught you off guard, Your Highness? Aww, does it hurt? I bet it hurts reaaaal bad, doesn't it? But it's nothing compared to what my brother felt! You will never be forgiven, you know. I will never forgive you!

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: You... You must be...

end.speaker: Fleche
end.line: You filthy monster! It's time to DIIIIE!

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Dimitri!

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Gah... P-Professor... Do it now!

end.speaker: Fleche
end.line: Agahhhh! B-Brother... Help... me...

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Rodrigue!

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Your Highness... Are you safe? Please tell me... it wasn't in vain...

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: This punishment... it was mine to bear.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: There are no sins or punishments... on the battlefield...

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: NO! Don't die... Please, don't die! Father, Stepmother, Glenn... They all died and left me behind. Rodrigue... Are you to join the ghosts who shadow my every move? This is my fault... I... I'm the one who killed you, as surely as though I had wielded the blade!

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Heh. Your Highness. You have one thing... terribly wrong. None of them... none of us... died for you. I'm dying for what I believe in... just as they did. Your life is your own. It belongs to no other, living or dead. Live for what you believe in. Dimitri... My boy... You really do look just like His Majesty...

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: What are you saying, Lambert?!

end.speaker: Lambert
end.line: I am heading to Duscur. And before you start, nothing you could say would change my mind. You worry too much, my friend. So far relations with Duscur have been going smoothly, wouldn't you say? You of all people should appreciate how critical these negotiations are.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Of course I do, but... for the king himself to make the journey... You must admit that it's dangerous. And His Highness is still so young. If the worst should happen...

end.speaker: Lambert
end.line: Even if the worst should happen, he would be OK. He's a smart boy, Rodrigue. Even if he should lose his father, I have no doubt that he will grow to be a good and respectable man.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Lambert...

end.speaker: Lambert
end.line: However... If he ever starts down the wrong path and I am not here to set him straight, I am trusting you to do so in my stead, old friend. Promise me.

end.speaker: Rodrigue
end.line: Lambert... My promise... I...
